quiz.title: Physics Grade 11: Elasticity & Springs
quiz.subtitle: Unit 3 Quiz 4 – Hooke’s Law, Spring Energy, and Combined Systems
quiz.subject: Physics
quiz.topic: Spring Constant, Original Length, Series Springs, Energy Storage

questions.question: A spring’s length is 24.0 cm when a load of 4.0 N is attached, and 28.0 cm when a load of 7.0 N is attached. What is its unstretched length?
A spring has a natural length of 20 cm. When a 0.4 kg mass is attached, its length becomes 24 cm. What is the spring constant k? (Use g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Force = mg = 4 N. Extension = 0.04 m. k = F/x = 4 / 0.04 = 100 N/m.

questions.question: Two identical springs (each k = 200 N/m) are connected in series. A 2 kg mass is attached. How much does the combination stretch? (Use g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Series equivalent k_eq = k/2 = 100 N/m. Force = mg = 20 N. Stretch = F/k_eq = 20 / 100 = 0.20 m.

questions.question: A spring can be stretched up to 0.15 m without exceeding its elastic limit. The spring constant is 400 N/m. What maximum mass can be hung without permanent deformation? (Use g = 10 m/s²)
questions.explanation: Max force = kx_max = 400 × 0.15 = 60 N. Mass = F/g = 60 / 10 = 6 kg.

questions.question: Spring A (k = 100 N/m) is stretched 0.1 m. Spring B (k = 200 N/m) is compressed 0.05 m. Which stores more elastic potential energy and by how much?
A spring’s length is 16.0 cm under a 9.0 N load and 22.0 cm under a 15.0 N load. Find its unstretched length.
A 2.0 kg mass stretches a spring by 0.10 m. If a 5.0 kg mass stretches the same spring by 0.25 m, what is the spring constant? (Use g = 10 m/s²)
A spring of length L and spring constant k = 300 N/m is cut into three equal parts. What is the spring constant of each part?
questions.explanation: For a spring, k ∝ 1/L. Cutting into 3 equal lengths triples k for each part: k_new = 3 × 300 = 900 N/m.

questions.question: How much work is done stretching a spring (k = 250 N/m) from an extension of 0.02 m to 0.08 m?
A vertical spring (k = 800 N/m) is compressed 0.05 m with a 0.1 kg ball on top. When released, how high does the ball rise above the uncompressed spring position? (Ignore air resistance, g = 10 m/s²)
